properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Yarra Ranges National Park and Surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Yarra Ranges National Park and Surrounds
  • There is a bushfire at Yarra Ranges National Park, north of Old Woods Point Road, that is not yet under control.
  • The Upper Yarra Recreational Reserve Campground has been closed.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Myrrhee. 
  • There is a bushfire at Myrrhee - 15 mile Creek that is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters are working to fully extinguish this fire.
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 2.20pm today.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 04:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Big Cord, Mirranatwa, Strachans, Victoria Valley
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Big Cord, Mirranatwa, Strachans, Victoria Valley.
  • The bushfire in the Grampians National Park - Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) is not yet under control. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 9:17am 7 February.
  • While the spread of the fire has been halted, there may still be active fire within the national park. 
  • Fire crews will continue to consolidate containment lines and monitor hot spots. 
  • Smoke may be visible in the area.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham & Cavendish. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. 
  • If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/02/2025 04:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Gerangamete, Barongarook.
  • There is a bushfire at Barongarook Westwoods Track that is now under control.
  • Fire Fighters will continue to patrol the fire overnight.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 3:34pm 7th February 2025.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas around Snowy Bluff, Mt Darling including Wonnangatta Valley
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas around Snowy Bluff, Mt Darling including Wonnangatta Valley.

  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 7.30am Friday 7 February 2025.
  • There is a small bushfire at Mt Darling - Snowy Bluff that is not yet under control.
  • Due to the fire in the adjacent Snowy Bluff - Mt Darling Wilderness, the McMillans Walking Trail between Moroka Junction Track and Moroka River Track is closed. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Goroke, Kaniva, Lawloit, Little Desert, Minimay, Nhill, Peronne
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Goroke, Kaniva, Lawloit, Little Desert, Minimay, Nhill, Peronne
  • This advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 12.20pm 6 February. 
  • This message applies to bushfire in the Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
  • There is still some fire activity in the Central block of the Little Desert National Park.
  •  Firefighters have slowed the spread of the fire for now, but the situation can change at any time. 
  • Fire Crews continue to treat hazardous trees, monitor hotspots and consolidate containment lines. 
  • Smoke may be visible in the area.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Kaniva-Edenhope Road is open.
  • There may be various local road closures. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 12:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Cooack, Dimboola, Little Desert, Winiam East, Duchembegarra, Gerang Gerung, Goroke, Grass Flat, Kiata, Nhill, Nurcoung, Pimpinio, Wail
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cooack, Dimboola, Duchembegarra, Gerang Gerung, Goroke, Grass Flat, Kiata, Little Desert, Nhill, Nurcoung, Pimpinio, Wail, Winiam East.
  • The bushfire in the Little Desert National Park is not yet under control. 
  • This message applies to the main part of the fire which occurred on Monday 27 January and is situated in the Central and Eastern Blocks of the Little Desert National Park. 
  • There is some fire activity in the area south of Lowloit.
  • Fire crews continue to treat hazardous tress, monitor hot spots and consolidate containment lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

People located within the area included in this message are able to resume normal activities. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Various local roads may be closed
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the southern part of Brimpaen, Cherrypool, Glenisla, Glenisla Crossing, the eastern side of Rocklands Reservoir, Wartook, Zumsteins.
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for the southern part of Brimpaen, Cherrypool, Glenisla, Glenisla Crossing, the eastern side of Rocklands Reservoir, Wartook, Zumsteins..
  • The bushfire in the Grampians National Park - Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) (Victoria Range) is not yet under control. 
  • This advice message replaces two previous Watch & Act messages issued at 9:08am and 9.26am 7 February. 
  • While the immediate spread of fire has been halted there is still active fire within the Grampians National park in the Wallaby Rocks area. 
  • Fire crews will continue to consolidate containment lines and monitor hot spots. 
  • Smoke will be visible in the area. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham and Cavendish. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park
  • For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website. 
Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • The fire in the Western Section of the Little Desert National Park has been contained.
  • Firefighters will continue to patrol this fire and respond to hot spots.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. 
  • The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill, known as the Yarram Gap Road fire, is under control. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 3:25pm 6 February.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
  • There is another fire in the western part of the Grampians known as the Wallaby Rocks Fire where fire crews continue to strengthen containment lines. Smoke may be visible from nearby communities. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 

Impacts in the Area:
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians National Park (Gariwerd)
  • The Grampians Tourist road from Dunkeld to Halls gap is open. 
  • Halls Gap township is open. 
  • While most of the Grampians National Park is closed, some popular areas and visitor sites are open to the public such as the Wonderland Loop Walk which includes The Pinnacle, Venus Baths and Grand Canyon. Chataqua Peak, Clematis Falls, Bullaces Glen and Boronia Peak are also open. 
  • Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks are closed.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit. 

Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000). 


This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 17/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Grampians National Park - Yarram Gap Road
Issue Date: Friday 07 February 2025, 12:47 pm
Next Update: Monday 17 February 2025, 12:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36557/moreinfo

This Community Information message is being issued for areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. 
- The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill, known as the Yarram Gap Road fire, is under control. 
- This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 3:25pm 6 February.
- Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
- Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
- There is another fire in the western part of the Grampians known as the Wallaby Rocks Fire where fire crews continue to strengthen containment lines. Smoke may be visible from nearby communities. 


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Grampians National Park - Yarram Gap Road

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Goroke, Kaniva, Minimay, Morea, Nurcoung, Peronne.
  • This Advice message replaces the advice message issued at 12.19 5 February. 
  • This message applies to the bushfire in the Central Block of the Little desert National Park.
  • There is some fire activity in the area south of Lawloit.
  • Fire crews continue to treat hazardous tress, monitor hot spots and consolidate containment lines.
  • Small areas of smoke with in the containment area may be visible.

There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings.  
  •  Review your fire survival plan.  
  •  If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Kaniva-Edenhope Road between Western Hwy and Natimuk-Frances Rd is closed. 
  •  Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. 
  •  Emergency services will remain in the area.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 12:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.location: Bendoc, Bonang, Buldah, Cabanandra, Deddick Valley, Delegate River, Dellicknora, Goongerah, Haydens Bog, Roaring Camp, Suggan Buggan, Tubbut, Wulgulmerang, Wulgulmerang East, Brumby, Chandlers Creek, Combienbar, Gelantipy, Yalmy
properties.webBody:
The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for people in parts of East Gippsland Forecast District.

  • Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce damaging winds, heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding and large hailstones in the warning area over the next several hours. 
  • Locations which may be affected include Chandlers Creek, Combienbar and Bonang.
  • Severe thunderstorms are no longer occurring in the North East and West and South Gippsland districts and the warning for these districts is CANCELLED.

The State Emergency Service advises that people should: 
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low-lying areas and floodwater. Avoid travel if possible.
  • Stay safe by avoiding dangerous hazards, such as floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees.
  • Be aware - heat, fire or recent storms may make trees unstable and more likely to fall when it's windy or wet.
  • Check that loose items, such as outdoor settings, umbrellas and trampolines are safely secured. Move vehicles under cover or away from trees.
  • Stay indoors and away from windows.
  • If outdoors, move to a safe place indoors. Stay away from trees, drains, gutters, creeks and waterways.
  • Stay away from fallen powerlines - always assume they are live.
  • Be aware that in fire affected areas, rainfall run-off into waterways may contain debris such as ash, soil, trees and rocks. Heavy rainfall may also increase the potential for landslides and debris across roads.
What you should do: 

  • Park your car undercover and away from trees.
  • Large hail is expected. Stay inside and away from windows.
  • Check that loose items such as outdoor furniture, umbrellas and trampolines are safely secured before the thunderstorm arrives. 
  • Stay inside if conditions outside appear dangerous.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so.
If you are driving:
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low lying areas and floodwater.
  • Be aware of road hazards such as mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • For road closure information, check the VicTraffic website, contact your local council or call VicRoads (13 11 70).
Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. 
For severe weather related emergency assistance from the SES, phone 132 500.
Impacts in your area:

The potential impacts of thunderstorms in your area include:
  • Building damage
  • Fallen power lines
  • Fallen trees and branches
  • Flash flooding
  • Overflowing drains and gutters
  • Damage to vehicles
  • Dangerous road conditions
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 10:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicstorms)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Incident Location: parts of East Gippsland Forecast District
Issue Date: Friday 07 February 2025, 07:01 pm
Next Update: Friday 07 February 2025, 10:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36582/moreinfo

The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for people in parts of East Gippsland Forecast District.
- Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce damaging winds, heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding and large hailstones in the warning area over the next several hours. 
- Locations which may be affected include Chandlers Creek, Combienbar and Bonang.
- Severe thunderstorms are no longer occurring in the North East and West and South Gippsland districts and the warning for these districts is CANCELLED. 



The State Emergency Service advises that people should: 
- If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low-lying areas and floodwater. Avoid travel if possible.
- Stay safe by avoiding dangerous hazards, such as floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees.
- Be aware - heat, fire or recent storms may make trees unstable and more likely to fall when it's windy or wet.
- Check that loose items, such as outdoor settings, umbrellas and trampolines are safely secured. Move vehicles under cover or away from trees.
- Stay indoors and away from windows.
- If outdoors, move to a safe place indoors. Stay away from trees, drains, gutters, creeks and waterways.
- Stay away from fallen powerlines - always assume they are live.
- Be aware that in fire affected areas, rainfall run-off into waterways may contain debris such as ash, soil, trees and rocks. Heavy rainfall may also increase the potential for landslides and debris across roads.

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cavendish, Mona Park, Mooralla, Victoria Point, Woohlpooer.
  • The bushfire in the Grampians National Park - Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) is not yet under control.  
  •  This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 9:24am 6 February. 
  •  While the spread of fire has been halted, there may still be active fire within the national park. 
  •  Fire crews will continue to consolidate containment lines and monitor hot spots. 
  •  Smoke may be visible in the area.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings.  
  • Review your fire survival plan.  
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham & Cavendish. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.  
Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park
  • For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website. 
Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. 
  • If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/02/2025 04:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Apollo Bay, Cape Horn, Cape Otway, Glenaire.
  • There is a bushfire at Hordern Vale - Binns Road that is under control.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice message issued Thursday 07 February 2025 at 10:48 AM.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Binns Road is closed.
  • Firefighters are continuing to patrol this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 08/02/2025 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au

properties.webHeadline:
Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce damaging winds, heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding and large hailstones in the warning area over the next several hours. Locations which may be affected include Chandlers Creek, Combienbar and Bonang.


Severe thunderstorms are no longer occurring in the North East and West and South Gippsland districts and the warning for these districts is CANCELLED.
